content.description: S.D.S. on a nice rail found under a small bulge.  Move up and over the bulge while trending left (up hill) to a small thank you crimp with your left.  Gravel over the top via mantle techniques to the finish.
content.location: Located on the south side of the lower part of "The Pass" where the "Land of The Slabs" meets the early up hill section of "The Pass."  It's one of the 1st problems that you will pass on your left as you began to hike up hill to the higher parts of "The Pass."

content.description: Start with left hand on obvious jug at hip height and right hand on sidepull crimp. Move right into a good flake. Find your way over the bulge into a variety of good crimps and slopers.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spotter.
content.location:
On the south east arete at the crest of the ridge. You can take the Sisters trail from East or West. Located in the gulley attaching the land of slabs to The Pass. Up the hill Northwest of

The Prince.

content.description: Start down low on a fat blunt arete.  Pull up into some side pulls and sloping lay backs.  Continue lay backing by leaning right on this small pillar to the finish.
content.location: Located on the east side of "The Pass" amoung a small set of cliff bands.  From "Prince Charles" you would head up hill and trend south for about 100 or so yards.

content.description: Start with in a left-facing corner and climb up and right over a small bulge to a nice horizontal rail.  Pull up onto and match hands on the rail.  Get your feet up nice and high as you press to the top out.  The crux is reaching the rail.
content.location: Located at the upper/top end of "The Pass."  The line sits on the Southern most side of one of nicer looking little round boulder.

content.description:
A short but fun route.  Starts on two sharp but positive crimps at eye level.  Move right to a triangular looking crimper and do some fancy footwork to gain a sidepull crimp on which you can match.  Then its up to a jug rail and over the top.

Although there wasn't any chalk on this before I got on it, I imagine someone has probably seen it and climbed it before?
content.location:
It's on the northwest side of the Bottleneck Pass. If you're facing

Tilt-a-whirl

, go left and skirt around the base of the large formation.  This ~10 foot crimp face is on the right, pretty easy to find.

content.description:
Start on the

Plastic Art

jug, traverse left on slopers and bad feet to

Cast in Bronze

. Heel hook and mantle.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.

content.description: Start back and to the right side of a giant wedged shape nose.  Move into a full body bear hug squeeze of madness.  As the wide hugging tapers to a thin point continue up and over the nose heading right or turning your back to the East at the last possible point on the line.  Slap your way to the finish.  Enjoy!!
content.location:
This is located on the upper North East slope of "The Pass." You can reach this line by following either the East or the West side of the Sisters Trail.

Per

Josh Thompson

: the GPS coordinates are: 39.629516, -105.348753.

content.description: Start on the left side of the block where there is a shallow left facing scoop/corner.  Left hand in the corner crack and right where most convenient.  Next, move straight up a sightly over hung face to jugs at the lip.  Follow the jugs on to the upper slab for a clean, fun finish.  A good line.
content.location:
Located on the East slope of "The Pass."  Walk the Sisters trail on the East side of the Brothers look out until you reach the steeper switch backing part of the Sisters trail.  about 2-3 hundred yards before actually reaching the Sisters formation turn left or West up a steep slope and navigate towards the top of a small bottle necked pass.

The line is just down hill (East) and North of "Prince Charles" by about 50 yards or so.

content.description:
Climb the shallow scope on the far RIGHT side of the "Stone Cavers Block."  Nice slab climbing but as for most of this block it's still needs more cleaning and more traffic.

NOTE:  More lines await ascents in the center of this very nice solid chunk of stone!!!
content.location: Located on the "Stone Cavers Block" in the saddle of the upper ridge of "The Pass."  Just down hill and to the SOUTH/EAST of "Tilt-A-Whirl."

content.description:
Start on the same jug as for "

Tilt-a-whirl

."  Make a cool (RH) cross to a perfect flat crimp.  Bring (LH) through to a small odd crimp out left.  Get set up and fire (LH) up to some of the worst slopers around.  Match up on the sloping dish and make a few more difficult moves to easier but (HB) climbing above.

Walk off right down a steep gully.

Great hard climbing on perfect rock.  And you can't beat the setting of this problem.  It's a new area classic!!  Go do it!!!!
content.location:
The approach is the same as for "The Pass,"  and the problem is on the same wall as "

Tilt-a-whirl

,"  which is located at the very top crest of "The Pass."  A little hard to find but worth the effort!!  A+ stone with great moves!!

content.description: Start sitting down on the left side of the block on a nice jug.  Follow the jug/crack system up the over hand until it's end.  Proceed to pull up and slightly right until you enter a mantel sequence and the finish.  Fun for the grade!!
content.location: Located about mid way up "The Pass."  It is just down hill and north/west of the problems "Colossal" and "Spine Crimp."

content.description: Start on crimps directly under a very small left facing/leaning corner.  Trend up and right on slopes and side pulls.  Very low ball with a safe landing.  Very nice for those new to the bouldering game!!!  In fact this whole boulder is nice in this fashion!!  A must do if your in "The Pass" area.
content.location: Located at the upper/top end of "The Pass."  The line sits on the Northern most side of one of nicer looking little round boulder.

content.description:
Start low on a big positive sloper.  There are two ways to go on this problem.  Left- gaining another sloper and a high step to mount onto this slab.  Or, right- moving to a left hand crimp followed by a high step to gain the slab above.

NOTE:  This is also the down climb for "

Prince Charles

."

Also a running, balance related, jump from a small rock slab onto the starting hold of this short problem can be done if you wish to by pass the problem just to do some more cleaning for "

Prince Charles

."  If this approach is taken be careful not to let your foot slip or you could end up hitting your face against the wall....  Good luck!!
content.location: Located on the West face of the "Prince Charles Block."  This boulder is situated in what is know as "The Pass."  This boulder sits to the NORTH/EAST of the main ridge line and bottle neck of "The Pass."  Best approached from the Sisters Trail's EAST side loop.  This trail system is best reached from the first parking lot.

content.description:
This problem climbs the SOUTH face of "The Stone Cavers Block" on its leftmost side.

Start with both hands on an ok sloper and grovel your way up onto the upper slab via a tricky mantel move.  A fun warm-up for the area.
content.location:
Located on the "Stone Cavers Block" in saddle of the upper ridge of "The Pass."  Just downhill and to the SOUTH/EAST of "

Tilt-A-Whirl

."

content.description:
Start down low in a small cave.  Climb the roof crack jams/lay backs up and onto the steep over hanging arete.  Follow the arete up and left all the way to it's virtual end and then roll over onto your right side and walk of the back.

Some sections are tall/insecure/and scary!!!  But so fun!
content.location: Located on the east side of "The Pass", about 30-50 yards (S/W), up hill from the "Prince Charles boulder."

content.description:
Start in the nice hands crack and climb it for about ten feet or so.  Then you reach a point where the crack goes left but you want to move right into a very small dihedral to meet up with a crack that is moving right towards a nice ledge and walk off.

Be careful pulling onto the final ledge system as the ground bellow drops away to add about another 15ft. of ground fall potential....  proceed with caution.  It's a nice crack problem!!
content.location: Located on the upper north/west side "The Pass"  Just up hill from "Prince Charles."

content.description: Climb up the face/crack on the East side of the "Prince Charles" boulder.
content.protection: Pads and a Spot.  Possible fall into a deep pit if not careful or well spotted.
content.location: This line is located on the North/East side of "The Pass" on the East face of the "Prince Charles" boulder.
